Instrument_Host.name: PIONEER VENUS PROBE BUS
Instrument_Host.description: The Pioneer Venus Multiprobe mission involved a spacecraft carrying four atmospheric entry probes to study the atmosphere of Venus. The mission aimed to investigate the atmosphere's structure, composition, clouds, radiation, energy exchange, and circulation patterns. The Multiprobe Bus, with a launch mass of 875 kg, featured a central Large Probe and three smaller probes arranged around it. Launched on August 8, 1978, the bus separated from the probes shortly before they entered the Venusian atmosphere, with the probes transmitting valuable data about the atmosphere's conditions. The bus was designed to survive only the upper atmospheric entry and was ultimately destroyed by atmospheric friction after transmitting data until it reached 110 km altitude on December 9, 1978. The total cost of the probes was $83 million.
